QUALITY
A selection of Westerns were reasonably well maintained. Nuwara Eliyas lacked the required quality. Uva/Uda Pussellawas showed no change, whilst the Low Growns were similar to last.
Forbes and Walker Tea Brokers
MOST COMPREHENSIVE WEBSITE ON TEA
www.forbestea.com
Page 2
Page 2
COMMENTS
Auction offerings totalled 6.0 M/Kgs, whilst noting a declining trend in the forthcoming sales. Improved demand and greater stability in prices this week.
Ex-Estate offerings comprised of 0.7 M/Kgs and here again, a declining trend. A selection of Westerns maintained reasonable levels of quality, whilst a greater majority still continued to be of fair average quality.
In the Western category, Best BOP/BOPF's - where quality was maintained - continued to sell around last, whilst the others were irregular following quality. In the Below Best category, a selection of improved BOP's gained by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the others together with teas at the lower end of the market were irregular. Corresponding BOPF's - A selection of improved teas gained by Rs. 50-80 per kg and more, whilst the others were irregular and easier by Rs. 20-40 per kg. BOPF's at the lower end appreciated by Rs. 50 per kg and more. Nuwara Eliyas' were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawas' commenced on a sluggish note and strengthened by up to Rs. 50 per kg by the close. Uvas' witnessed mixed demand and an irregular trend in prices.
High & Medium Grown CTC teas showed no significant change in the overall pricing, whilst the corresponding Low Grown types were firm and tended dearer.
There appeared to be less activity from shippers to the UK, the continent and South Africa. Shippers to Japan and China appeared reasonably strong, whilst shippers to the Middle East and the CIS perhaps in particular showed improved activity.
Low Growns totalled approximately 2.5 M/Kgs, with fair demand witnessed in the Leafy, Semi-Leafy, Tippy and Premium categories.
In the Leafy and Semi-Leafy catalogues, well-made BOP1's maintained at last levels, whilst Below Best and bolder varieties were irregular. Teas at the bottom and well-made OP1's held firm, whilst the balance were irregular. Well-made OP's together with the cleaner Below Best and shorter varieties appreciated, whilst the others were firm on last. High-priced OPA's were dearer, whilst the balance sold around last levels. High-priced PEK's were easier, whilst the Best sold at last levels. However, the balance eased. A selection of high-priced PEK1's gained, whilst the others declined.
In the Tippy catalogue, Select Best FBOP's appreciated, whilst the balance were firm to dearer. Well-made FF1's and cleaner Below Best types were firm to dearer, whilst the balance were irregular following quality.
In the Premium catalogue, Very Tippy Teas together with Best were dearer, whilst the Below Best too were dearer to a lesser extent. Balance were irregular.
SRI LANKA TEA PRODUCTION - JUNE 2025
June 2025/2024/2023
*
Sri Lanka Tea Production
for the month of June 2025 totalled 21.69 M/Kgs, witnessing a decline of 1.46 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 23.15 M/Kgs of June 2024. All elevations show a decline in comparison with the corresponding month of 2024.
* Compared to 23.09 M/Kgs of June 2023, the corresponding month in the year 2025 shows a decline of 1.40 M/Kgs (Refer table below).
JANUARY-JUNE 2025/2024/2023
* January-June 2025 cumulative production totalled 135.74 M/Kgs, recording an increase of 7.78 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 127.96 M/Kgs of January-June 2024. All elevations recorded an increase in comparison with the corresponding period of 2024.
* Compared to 134.66 M/Kgs of January-June 2023, cumulative production of 2025 shows an increase of 1.08 M/Kgs. On a cumulative basis, all elevations except for the Mid Grown Elevation  have shown negative variances when compared with the same period in the year 2023 (Refer table below).
(Refer statistical details on Page No. 11)
SRI LANKA TEA EXPORTS - JUNE 2025
Key Highlights:
*
Sri Lanka Tea Exports for the month was recorded at 23.27 M/Kgs - (Increase of 2.31 M/Kgs YoY)
* Cumulative Exports totalled 126.80 M/Kgs (Increase of 7.69 M/Kgs YoY) in comparison with January-June 2024 total of 119.11 M/Kgs
*
F.O.B Value for the month recorded at Rs. 1,714.08 (USD 5.72), recording a decline of Rs. 50.93 (decrease of USD 0.09) against the corresponding period of 2024. Cumulative FOB value declined by Rs. 25.95 in comparison with the corresponding period of 2024, whilst the to-date USD earnings continued to show an overall improvement in all categories except for Packeted Tea
*
Iraq continues to maintain top position amongst leading importer countries of Ceylon Tea for the period January-June 2025, whilst Libya remains at 2
nd
place
June 2025/2024
* Tea Exports for the month of June 2025 totalled 23.27 M/Kgs, showing an increase of 2.31 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 20.96 M/Kgs of June 2024. All categories have recorded positive variances, except for the Tea in Bulk category. FOB value in June 2025 was recorded at Rs. 1,714.08, a decrease of Rs. 50.93 YoY compared to Rs. 1,765.01 of June 2024. In USD terms, the month of June also witnessed a decline of USD 0.09 in comparison with the corresponding period in the year 2024 (Refer table below).
JANUARY-JUNE 2025/2024
* January-June 2025 cumulative exports totalled 126.80 M/Kgs, recording a positive variance of 7.69 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 119.11 M/Kgs of January-June 2024. All segments, except for Tea in Bulk have recorded positive variances against the same period of the previous year.
* FOB value for the period stood at Rs. 1,745.10, a decrease of Rs. 25.95 (increase of USD 0.09) vis-à-vis Rs. 1,771.05 of January-June 2024.
* All categories except for Instant Tea recorded negative variances in LKR terms in FOB value, whilst gains were recorded in USD terms in all categories except for Tea Packets when compared to the corresponding period in 2024 (Refer table below).
Iraq ranks at No. 01 amongst major importers of Ceylon Tea with a total of 18.71 M/Kgs, an increase of 28% YoY in January-June 2025 against the previous year's 14.67 M/Kgs, with Libya coming in 2
nd
Place with 11.47 M/Kgs, an improvement of 280% ahead of Russia in 3
rd
place who have witnessed a significant decline of 14% YoY with 11.20 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 13.05 M/Kgs recorded in 2024. The U.A.E with 8.82 M/Kgs (26% decrease YoY) followed by Türkiye who have recorded 7.90 M/Kgs (8% decrease YoY) surpassing Iran at 6.42 M/Kgs (2% increase YoY),). Chile has secured 7
th
place with 5.51 M/Kgs edging over China's 5.11 M/Kgs, Saudi Arabia at 4.17 M/Kgs and Azerbaijan at 3.79 M/Kgs for the year in progress.
(Refer statistical details on Page Nos. 8 and 9)
FORBES & WALKER TEA BROKERS (PVT) LTD SALE OF - 22ND/ 23RD JULY 2025
Forbes and Walker Tea Brokers
MOST COMPREHENSIVE WEBSITE ON TEA
www.forbestea.com
Page 3
Page 3
MARKET
Good general demand
HIGH GROWN TEAS
BOP
Best Western's, where quality was maintained, continued to sell around last, whilst the others were irregular. In the Below Best category, select invoices gained by Rs. 20-40 per kg following quality, whilst the others together with teas at the lower end of the market were irregular. Nuwara Eliya's were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawa's were marginally easier. Uva's - Select invoices appreciated sharply, whilst the others were barely steady.
BOPF
Best Western's, where quality was maintained, continued to sell around last week's levels, whilst the others were irregular. In the Below Best category, select improved teas gained by Rs. 50-80 per kg and more, whilst the others were irregular and often Rs. 20-40 per kg easier. Teas at the lower end appreciated by Rs. 50 per kg and more. Nuwara Eliya's were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawa's which commenced firm on last week's levels, gained by Rs. 20-40 per kg towards the closure of the sale. Uva's were irregular and mostly easier.
OP/OPA
Well-made varieties were firm on last levels, whilst the others and poorer sorts were firm to dearer by Rs. 20 per kg.
PEKOE/PEKOE1
Flavoury PEK's were dearer by Rs. 20-40 per kg and more at times, whilst the Orthodox Leafy PEK's were firm. Best PEK1's were dearer by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the others were irregular. Best Rotovane PEK's remained mostly firm to irregularly easier by Rs. 40-60 per kg, whilst the others and poorer sorts sold around last levels.
FBOP/FBOPF1
Select Best flavoury FBOP/FBOPF1's were firm to dearer by Rs. 20 per kg, whilst the poorer sorts were mostly unsold. Better Orthodox FBOP/FBOPF1's appreciated by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the others and teas at the lower end held firm.

OFF GRADES
FGS1/FGS
Teas in the Best category were firm to dearer. Improved Below Best varieties which commenced firm appreciated by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the others maintained. Teas at the lower end of the market were easier. Low Growns - Best varieties maintained. Below Best varieties where quality was maintained were firm, whilst the others declined. Poorer sorts experienced a sharp and significant decline with most teas remaining unsold due to unsuitable bids. CTC - Clean leaf varieties were firm, whilst the others declined by Rs. 10-30 per kg
BROKENS
Reducer varieties in the Best category together with the clean leaf sorts maintained, whilst the others were lower by Rs. 10-30 per kg.
BOP1A
Main Grade reducer varieties in the Best category maintained, whilst the balance were easier by Rs. 10-20 per kg. Below Best varieties were easier by Rs. 20-30 per kg and more, whilst the poorer sorts were firm on last.

Low Grown Best varieties were substantially dearer by Rs. 60-80 per kg, whilst the Below Best varieties remained firm. The poorer sorts were easier by Rs. 20-40 per kg. Best High and Medium Grown CTC's were dearer by Rs. 20 per kg, whilst the others followed a similar trend. Best Low Grown CTC's were dearer by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the others remained firm.
DUST
Clean leaf secondaries were dearer by Rs. 40 per kg, whilst the poorer sorts declined by Rs. 20-40 per kg. The Low Grown Best varieties appreciated by Rs. 40-60, whilst the others were dearer by Rs. 20-30 per kg.

FBOP/FBOP1

BOP

BOP1

OP1

OP
Well-made OP's together with the cleaner Below Best and shorter varieties appreciated, whilst the balance were firm.
OPA
High-priced OPA's appreciated, whilst the balance sold around last levels.
PEKOE
High-priced PEK's were easier, whilst the Best sold at last levels. However, the balance eased. A selection of high-priced PEK1's gained, whilst the others declined.
BOPF
BOPF's, in general, sold around last levels.
FBOPF/FBOPF1
Very Tippy Teas together with Best were dearer, whilst the Below Best too were dearer to a lesser extent. Balance were irregular.  Well-made FF1's together with cleaner Below Best varieties were firm to dearer, whilst the balance were irregular following quality.

CROP AND WEATHER
For the period 16 - 22  July 2025
Western/Nuwara Eliya Regions
The Wesrtern and Nuwara Eliya regions reported rain and windy conditions throughout the week. According to the Department of Meteorology, fairly heavy showers are expected in both regions in the week ahead.
Uva/Uda Pussellawa Regions
The Uva and Uda Pussellawa regions reported bright weather throughout the week. Showers are expected in both regions in the week ahead according to the Department of Meteorology.
Low Growns
Bright mornings and occasional evening showers were reported in the Low Grown Region throughout the week. The Department of Meteorology expects rain in the Low Grown Region in the week ahead.
Crop Intake
The Nuwara Eliya Region reported an increase in the crop intake, whilst the Western, Uva, Uda Pussellawa and Low Grown regions reported a decline.

MOMBASA AUCTION
SALE OF - 21ST & 22ND JULY 2025 (SALE NO. 29)
Good general demand prevailed for the 206,980 packages (13,935,152.00 kilos) on offer with 42.55% unsold.
MARKETS
Pakistan Packers lent strong support with more enquiry from Yemen and other Middle Eastern countries. Kazakhstan and other CIS states showed less interest while Afghanistan were active. There was increased participation from Bazaar with maintained support from Egyptian Packers. UK were active but more selective while Russia reduced enquiry. Sudan were absent with South Sudan more active. Local Packers showed some interest with Somalia active at the lower end of the market.
OFFERINGS
Leaf Grades                 -      114,320 packages (7,499,638.00 kilos) - 50.54% unsold.
Dust Grades               -        72,160 packages (5,379,704.00 kilos) - 36.25% unsold.
Secondary Grades       -        20,500 packages (1,055,810.00 kilos) - 20.20% unsold.
LEAF GRADES (M2 & M3)
BP1:
Best - Less enquiry and were more irregular ranging between mostly easier by USC38, USC67, USC69 and USC74 while some teas up to USC17 dearer.
Brighter - Firm to USC14 below previous levels.
Mediums - KTDA mediums were steady to USC3 easier while plantation mediums saw improved interest and gained up to USC22.
Lower Medium - Mostly eased by up to USC14 but select lines were up to USC15 above previous levels.
Plainer - Firm to USC8 dearer to easier by up to USC7.
PF1:
Best - Irregular interest and varied between steady to USC21 dearer to mostly easier by up to USC24.
Brighter - Easier by up to USC11.
Mediums - KTDA mediums were irregular varying between firm to USC7 above last levels to easier by up to USC14 while plantation mediums shed up to USC11 but select lines were up to USC4 above previous levels.
Lower Medium - Met irregular enquiry and ranged between USC8 dearer to easier by up to USC10.
Plainer - Steady to USC6 dearer but some lines lost up to USC4.

Plainer - Irregular ranging between steady to USC9 dearer to USC6 below previous levels.

Lower Medium - Firm to dearer by up to USC14.
Plainer - Irregularly easier by up to USC10 but select teas gained up to USC9.

SECONDARY GRADES (S1)
In the Secondary Catalogues, BPs held value with cleaner types up to USC23 dearer while PFs were firm. Clean well sorted coloury Fannings held value with similar DUSTs steady. Other Fannings sold at previous rates with DUSTs firm. BMFs were readily absorbed above previous levels.

BANGLADESH AUCTION
SALE OF - 21ST JULY 2025 (SALE NO. 11)
CTC LEAF: 43,610 packages of tea on offer met with a strong demand.
BROKENS: Good liquoring Brokens were a strong market and were mostly dearer by upto Tk.5/- and more. Medium varieties met with more enquiry and were fully firm. Plainer sorts once again met with a fair demand and were about steady with fair withdrawals. BLF teas were again a good market and were firm to dearer.
FANNINGS : Good liquoring Fannings were a stronger market and were firm to slightly dearer. Good and Medium teas were an improved market and were mostly firm. Plainer sorts once again met with a fair demand and were about steady with fair withdrawals. BLF teas were again a good market and were firm to dearer.
DUST: 11,443 packages of tea on offer met with an improved demand. Good liquoring Dusts met with a good competition and were fully firm to slightly dearer. Their Mediums also sold well closely following quality. Plain/BLF Dusts were barely steady with a few withdrawals. Blenders lent strong support with fair interest from the Loose tea buyers.
COMMENTS: There was a stronger demand this week with fair improvement in price levels. Blenders lent stronger support with Loose tea buyers participating quite actively for the brighter varieties.
It was evident throughout the sale that the buyers strictly followed quality which showed an improvement over last.
Dusts were a dearer market.
Our Catalogue: (Sale 11) Avg : Tk 251.31, Sold 82.58% , (Sale 10) Avg : Tk 245.44, Sold 72.12%

KOLKATA SALE  CTC MARKET
MARKET REPORT:
Market opened to good demand. Liquoring Assams selling around last levels. Fannings and  BPS tending easier and seeing some withdrawals. Medium and plainer category not seen yet.
BUYING PATTERN:
Western India: Good Support on the better teas
HUL: Operating
Exporters: Some enquiry on bolder brokens and fannings
TCPL: Quiet so far
Other Internal/Local: Fair enquiry
KOLKATA SALE  ORTHODOX MARKET
MARKET REPORT:
Market opened to strong demand. Few tippy teas on offer selling readily. Well made Whole Leaf and Brokens selling at firm to ocassionally dearer rates. GFOP witnessing improved demand and selling readily. Remainder Whole Leaf and Brokens irregular around last.
Fannings and Cleaner Secondaries around last levels.
BUYING PATTERN:
Middle East : Active
CIS:  Good Support
HUL: Very selective
KOLKATA SALE  DUST MARKET
MARKET REPORT:
Liquoring Assams irregularly easier with PD declining. Remainder following a similar trend.
BUYING PATTERN:
HUL - Active
WI - Active
West Bengal Manufacturing - Selective
Courtesy -  J Thomas & Company Private Limited
JAKARTA AUCTION
SALE OF - 18TH JULY 2025 (SALE NO. 29)
CTC LEAF
The total CTC leaf teas sold this week was 71.99%(1,294,141.81kgs) of the total offering of 1,797,746.60Kgs DEMAND: - Selective demand for best, good & better medium. Reduced demand on plainer teas.
MARKET: - Very limited volume of teas were on offer from the best & good tea segment which sold at irregular levels. Better
medium declined by Rs 2-4., medium sorts were barely steady to easier. Lower medium and plainer teas continue to face withdrawals with very limited weight of teas sold at Rs 2-4 lower than last.
BUYING PATTERN: - Major blenders were the mainstay of the market with 50.23% off take of the entire CTC sold. Regional buyers were selective on the best and good liquoring sorts. Internal buyers continued to be subdued. Middle east and Russian exporters continued to be fairly active on blacker sorts. Select Iraqi buying was witnessed.
ORTHODOX LEAF
Demand:- Good Demand.
Market:- All teas sold barely steady to easier except for the fanning grade which saw larger discount compared to last week.
Buying Pattern:- Russian and CIS buyers were selective active along with Internal buyers.Middle east shippers lent fair support on whole leaf grades and broken.
CTC DUST
DEMAND: - Selective or rather subdued on best & good teas, fair for the better medium, reduced demand for the remainders.
MARKET: - CTC dust offer this week was at 530,490.91Kgs of which 388,110.55kgs were sold (73.16%). Limited quantity of Best & good teas sold substantially easier. Better medium teas sold easier by Rs 2 to 4 or more, others too eased by Rs 2 to 4 with continued out list on the lower medium and plainer teas especially, the browner sorts.
BUYING PATTERN: - Major blenders continued to be very choosy. Regional and local packeteers were less active on the best & good teas. Up country buyers were subdued. Exporters to Russia, Middle east were selective this week on blacker sorts.
ORTHODOX DUST
DEMAND: - Good demand on primary at easier prices compared to last, fair on the Medium grown & secondaries.
MARKET: - High grown primary dust fetched easier prices with lack of the lone up country buyer who operated strongly last week., medium grown sold irregularly easier. Secondaries sold easier with fair withdrawals.
BUYING PATTERN: -Regional & local packateers were fairly active on primary dusts. Exporters were very choosy at easier
Courtesy J.Thomas & Co. Pvt. Ltd
